articles.headline: Credit Crisis Spreading New Jitters in Europe
articles.snippet: Many nations in Europe are now feeling an autumn chill of slackening economies and warnings of further market upheaval.
articles.abstract: Many nations in Europe are now feeling an autumn chill of slackening economies and warnings of further market upheaval.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT, Oct. 25 — Europe, which once hoped to avoid major fallout from the summer’s credit crisis, is now feeling an autumn chill of slackening economies and warnings of further market upheaval.

articles.headline: President Visits Scene and Promises Help
articles.snippet: President Bush toured fire-ravaged Southern California as the threat began to ebb and the focus shifted to the investigation of possible arson.
articles.abstract: President Bush toured fire-ravaged Southern California as the threat began to ebb and the focus shifted to the investigation of possible arson.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 — President Bush toured Southern California on Thursday as investigators got down to the work of determining how one sunny fall day last weekend erupted into a 16-fire storm now in its fifth day.

articles.headline: Saudi King Tries to Grow Modern Ideas in Desert
articles.snippet: King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia is staking $12.5 billion on a bid to catch up with the West in science and technology.
articles.abstract: King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia is staking $12.5 billion on a bid to catch up with the West in science and technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Oct. 25  On a marshy peninsula 50 miles from this Red Sea port, King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia is staking $12.5 billion on a gargantuan bid to catch up with the West in science and technology.

articles.headline: Cement Industry Is at Center of Climate Change Debate
articles.snippet: As cement plants emit 5 percent of all carbon dioxide emissions, the main cause of global warming, making cement means making pollution.
articles.abstract: As cement plants emit 5 percent of all carbon dioxide emissions, the main cause of global warming, making cement means making pollution.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, Oct. 23 — In booming economies from Asia to Eastern Europe, cement is literally the glue of progress. A binding agent that holds the other ingredients that together make concrete, cement is a crucial component in buildings and roads — which is why some 80 percent of it is made and used in emerging economies.

articles.headline: A No-Nonsense Style Honed as Advocate and First Lady
articles.snippet: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has been described as an organized, disciplined, methodical manager.
articles.abstract: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has been described as an organized, disciplined, methodical manager.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 — Hillary Rodham Clinton needs her rest. She shuns the nocturnal habits of her husband — the 2 a.m. staff calls, the all-hours games of hearts. “It doesn’t suit my body rhythms,” said Mrs. Clinton, who typically sleeps six or seven hours, sometimes beside the briefing book she had been reading.

articles.headline: Macy’s and Hilfiger Strike Exclusive Deal
articles.snippet: Tommy Hilfiger agreed to sell his biggest clothing lines exclusively at Macy’s, a deal that could rattle the department store industry.
articles.abstract: Tommy Hilfiger agreed to sell his biggest clothing lines exclusively at Macy’s, a deal that could rattle the department store industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: The designer Tommy Hilfiger has agreed to sell his biggest clothing lines exclusively at Macy’s, both companies are expected to announce today in a deal that could rattle the department store industry.

articles.headline: Blair’s Advance for Memoir Said to Be About $9 Million
articles.snippet: The rights to publish Tony Blair’s memoir were bought by two divisions of Random House: Alfred A. Knopf in the U.S. and Canada and Hutchinson in Britain.
articles.abstract: The rights to publish Tony Blair’s memoir were bought by two divisions of Random House: Alfred A. Knopf in the U.S. and Canada and Hutchinson in Britain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tony Blair, the former prime minister of Britain, has agreed to sell his memoir for an advance of around $9 million, according to a person with knowledge of the negotiations.

articles.headline: Seeking Savings, Employers Help Smokers Quit
articles.snippet: Many companies are seeking to reduce their medical bills by paying for programs to help employees stop smoking.
articles.abstract: Many companies are seeking to reduce their medical bills by paying for programs to help employees stop smoking.
articles.lead_paragraph: Corporate America has made big strides toward the smoke-free workplace. Its next goal: the smoke-free worker.

articles.headline: Merrill’s Chief Is Said to Consider a Bid to Merge
articles.snippet: E. Stanley O’Neal reportedly floated the possibility of a merger to Wachovia without board approval.
articles.abstract: E. Stanley O’Neal reportedly floated the possibility of a merger to Wachovia without board approval.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facing billions of dollars in losses from the subprime mortgage crisis, Merrill Lynch chairman and chief executive, E. Stanley O’Neal, floated the idea of a merger with a large bank, a foray that angered Merrill’s board and could cost him his job, according to people close to the beleaguered Wall Street firm.
articles.byline: By JENNY ANDERSON and LANDON THOMAS, Jr

articles.headline: Who’s Going to Take the Financial Weight?
articles.snippet: Much of the credit risk transferred through a bewildering  array of options, swaps, swaptions and other complex instruments ended just where it used to end. With the banks.
articles.abstract: Much of the credit risk transferred through a bewildering  array of options, swaps, swaptions and other complex instruments ended just where it used to end. With the banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The transfer of risk was supposed to be the great advance brought to the world by financial engineers. They developed exotic derivative products that enabled risks to be sliced and diced in all manner of ways.

articles.headline: Mexicans Miss Money From Relatives Up North
articles.snippet: After years of strong increases, the amount of migrant money flowing to Mexico has stagnated.
articles.abstract: After years of strong increases, the amount of migrant money flowing to Mexico has stagnated.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL RODEO, Mexico — For years, millions of Mexican migrants working in the United States have sent money back home to villages like this one, money that allows families to pay medical bills and school fees, build houses and buy clothes or, if they save enough, maybe start a tiny business.
